params.text:
Human activities contribute many toxic metals to the environment:

  1. Burning fossil fuels by driving cars and heating our homes releases chromium, zinc, cadmium and lead into the air.
  2. Then, there's the issue of all the trash:
    • Electronic waste can release lead, mercury, and cadmium into the soil and water.
    • Landfills can release many toxic metals into the soil and water.
    • Waste incineration (burning trash) can release lead and mercury into the air.

hotspots.header: Urban and domestic sources of toxic metals

params.text: The removal of metals in wastewater is done by filtration and other treatment processes. While treatment technologies have improved, some toxic metals remain in wastewater that runs directly into our rivers and streams.

Industry is a leading source of toxic metals in the environment. For example,

  1. Metal smelting and refining (extracting and purifying metals from rock) can release nickel, cadmium, lead, copper, zinc, mercury, and chromium into the air.
  2. Industrial waste water can directly pollute rivers and streams with toxic metals, and leach into surrounding soil and groundwater.
  3. The chemical industry can directly pollute air and water with toxic metals.
  4. The combustion of fossil fuels for electricity can release cadmium, nickel, mercury, and vanadium into the air and soil.

Geogenic means 'of or relating to the history of the earth'. In other words, it's natural! Rocks naturally contain a mixture of metals, including toxic metals. When rocks are worn down by wind or water, or blasted into the air in a volcanic eruption, the metals in these rocks find a new home in water, soil, and air.

Mining is considered a major source of toxic metal pollution in the environment. Because mining literally digs and grinds up rocks that were once buried and undisturbed, it comes as no surprise that toxic metals in those rocks are released into the air, soil, and water around a mining site.

 

Common toxic metals that are released into the environment from mining practices include arsenic, mercury, lead, zinc, chromium, cadmium, and nickel.

Agricultural (farming) practices release toxic metals into the environment in several ways:

  1. Burning fossil fuels releases chromium, zinc, cadmium, and lead into the air

  2. Inorganic fertilizers (chemicals that are used to make plants grow faster) can release chromium, cadmium, copper, zinc, nickel, manganese, and lead into the soil and water.

  3. Pesticides (chemicals that are used to kill bugs and pests) can contain copper, zinc, cadmnium, lead, and arsenic, releasing these metals into the air, soil, and water.

  4. Manure and other livestock-related organic waste can release zinc, copper, nickel, lead, cadmnium, chromium, arsenic, and mercury into the soil and water.
Volatilization  is when a toxic metal dissolves into water, and water containing that metal evaporates into the air. It is one of the ways that metals get into the air.

You might have heard that certain types of seafood are high in mercury and should only be eaten in moderation. Most toxic metals aren't directly absorbed by the animals we eat, but they can build up in those animals after going through chemical transformations in the environment. This is just one example of how studying metals in the environment is a complex science!

Toxic metals get stored in sediments (mud) at the bottom of rivers, lakes, and oceans. As these sediments get stirred up, some of those metals can dissolve in water, leading to chemical transformations, volatilization, or uptake by animals and plants.

backgroundImageAltText: Toxic heavy metals get into the environment in miriad ways, from natural sources like rock erosion and volcanic activity, to anthropogenic (human-made) sources such as fossil fuel combustion, agriculture, mining, and industrial waste.
